label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, May 17, 1944
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, informing her of his brother, Armant’s, return to sea duty, recounting a story of a fight some of their tenants had the night before, and relaying the atmosphere of the continental United States as was told to him by a coworker who had just returned from leave.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, informing her of his brother, Armant’s, return to sea duty, recounting a story of a fight some of their tenants had the night before, and relaying the atmosphere of the continental United States as was told to him by a coworker who had just returned from leave.

metadata.label: Access Note
metadata.value: All rights reserved. For more information and reuse requirements contact The College of Charleston Library, Charleston SC 29424.

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications
metadata.value: 300 dpi, 24-bit depth color, Epson Expression 10000XL, Archival Masters are tiffs.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
May 17, 1944
Dear Gertie,
What do you think[,]Armant has left. He refused to
like the place or take any interest in the work, only spoke of
going to sea and said that his true love lay in the bounding
waves. But you cannot imagine who he has gone with and wanted
to go with. None other than that drunken captain he was with
in New Olreans that he complained about and said that he just
could not stand. You remember, because you made the classical
remark that you thought that was a lot of Hoey and that Armant
really wanted to get drunk. Well anyway he is gone and we are
once more the two of us in this apartment. It is rather ludicriou
because we bought the place in a way so that we three would have
a home to l[i]ve in together. Morris and I had planned how wonderfu
l it would be to have the three brothers together and Morris
worked so hard to get him out here. It was unbelievable his
persistence[,] his constant dogging of captains etc to obtain
permission for Armant to be transferrred and now after a short
time hardly longer that a sigh and a whistel he is gone.
Somethi ng happened so funny the other evening.
One of our tennants is a woman married to a hard faced speechless
man. they come and go without a word, stony faced and grim.
We had never even arouse[d] sufficent interest to wonder what they
did or were doing, but suddenly their life was thrown open to us
like a book and we realized the boredom that exi sted at least on
one side. At ten thirty we were awakened by the womens loud
voice somewhat strengthed by stonrg sdrink. She shrieked
"there you lie, am I bored. You do nothing, nothing, just lie
there." There was moments silince in which I presume he told
her not to talk so [L]oud as she would awakened the landlords.
This brought forth a tirade "those lieutenants, those NAVY
lieutenants what have they ever done for me. What do I owe them"
This was followed by a bronx cheer emitted with considerable
gusto and a loud "nothing". Morris by this time had his chin
on the window sill and was gazing interestingly across the court
yard. Armnt lay on his bed drinking It all in and giving
encouragement in a low voice with " you tell them fat lady"
Absolutely he is not Gen[T]lemen, there you lie and he does nothing,
it is a crying shame that is what it is."
In this midst of this familly scene a tom cat let out a wail
and then another and another. In a short time there must have
been twenty tom cats sitting outside tha apartment house lifting
their voices up to the sky. The cause was a shell colored
persian cat that inhabits one of our apartmnots and apparently
was irrestibly a tractive to a[L]l the male tom cats for blocks
around. After a council of war we decided that we either had to
kill the cat or get her a mate. By joint consent Armant and
I decided to let Morris handle the si tuation, but he went to
[End Page 1]
sleep and nothing was done. For some reasen the aparmtnet dwell
ers who I cons[i]der very much like cliff dwellers have all come
to swords points with one nother and they waylay Morris and
I and compalin about one another. "that old hag" one will say.
She phoned me last night and said that I was making too much noi
se. I never make a sound but she stays in her room and gets dru
nk all the time.  Then the women who gets drunk all the time
telephones and say_s that the people below her are impossible,
have no thought for anyone but themselves and play their radio
until the wee hours of the morning. It is very funny. I can
see how mad you would get, and how you would tell Rose to take
charge of the whole matter.
I talked to a boy who had just co[M]e back from a leave in
the mainland and he said that it was uhbelievable. No one
seemed to know there was a war going on exce[p]t for the fact they
wanted the war to be over in a hurry. They were tired of ration_
ingand all the petty annoyances that goes with war. Knew that
fighting was going on somehwere in the world but not quite sure
where. Also he said that the girls absolutley fell over the m[e]n.
He would walk into a bar and there would be crowds of girls, but
nice girls who would talk to him and after a while he would pick
one out and say you are my date for the evening and she would be
delighted. Sort of different from the days when a man would
try to pick a girl up and would be looked at as if he was the w
wickedest thing in the world. He also said that the only
rationing he noticed was gasoline. As far as food was concerend
ther[e] was alomost more than enough to eat. Drinks were to be had
everywhere and night clubs were opened until the wee hours of the
morning. It all sounds pretty gay and festive to me. But then
you cannot blame people. You would not wan t them to sit in their
homes and moan about the poor boys fighting. They might just as
well have a good time and enjoy themselves because moping never
did anyone any good in the world. The only thing that I cannot
understad are the strikes. They are beyond me because the
workers are really getting a good salary. The government
gives Montgomery Ward Hell when they are not even manufacturing
war materials, but when the xxxxxxx foremen strike in the factory
and hold up all the manufaturing of aeroplanes they do nothing.
Look what they did with Lewis when he closed all the coal mines
with his stikes. Absolutely defied the government and employers.
Broke the law at every turn, held up the war effort and caused
a great many deaths. They did nothing to him at all. But when
Montgomery Ward stands on its own legal rights, really for the
protection of its workers the governemnt takes it over. Well
What can you expect with that man biddle in their. Remember
when we ment and had to have our meals with him. We thought he
was such a pompous Ass.
Goodbye darling. I hope everything is going well with 
you and that I will see you soon. With all my love.
Sidney J. Legendre
[End Page 2]
